title: NSW legislation changes could mean husbands would need to be told 'yes' before having sex with wife
text:
Husbands will have to get a clear 'yes' from their wives before jumping into bed together under sweeping new sexual consent laws that experts have slammed as a 'waste of time'.

The current laws in NSW state a person only refuses consent if they physically or verbally refuse sex.

The new laws, which are similar to Victoria and Tasmania, means a person does not consent simply by not resisting sex.

The proposed reforms have been slammed as 'complex' by Australian Lawyers Alliance Greg Barns (pictured) who claims that laws are fair enough the way they are

Australian Lawyers Alliance Greg Barns said the changes were unnecessary and a definite mood killer because 'we know sex doesn’t happen like that'.

Rape and Domestic Violence Services Australia, Karen Willis, said just because a woman says 'I do' at the altar doesn't mean it is for life.

The landmark proposal comes after a NSW Law Reform Commission review of rape laws.

The review was sparked after high-profile rape case involving Luke Lazarus who convicted and then acquitted of raping 18-year-old virgin Saxon Mullins on her first night out in Sydney's King Cross.

Mr Barns said current consent laws were already fair and clear and didn't need reform.

'It’s almost as if you want people to have a contractual analysis,' Mr Barns told The Daily Telegraph.

'These cases are complex in law in relation to consent and we think it is fairly workable as it is.'

Executive officer at Rape and Domestic Violence Services Australia, Karen Willis, supported the proposed changes which would encourage partners to talk about sex

Ms Willis said shes supported the proposed changes which would encourage partners to talk about sex.

Lazarus, 28, was convicted in 2015 of raping Mullins in an alleyway behind his dad's nightclub two years earlier

'Just because you say ‘I do’ once does not mean that you have to say it for the rest of your life,' she said.

'If you are not 100 per cent sure the person is consenting and don't want to ask, just stop.'

Lazarus, 28, was convicted in 2015 of raping Mullins in an alleyway behind his dad's nightclub two years earlier.

He was sentenced to at least three years jail but appealed the verdict and acquitted on the basis his belief in consent was reasonable.

Saxon was on her first night out in the popular Sydney party strip when the incident happened.
